0.rationale:
Thinking:  
• I’m at (4,9) on the top edge; moving UP would hit the wall.  
• LEFT or RIGHT are safe but keep me on the rim.  
• Moving DOWN to (4,8) is safe and starts me toward the apple in my column at (4,3) while also pulling me off the edge for more maneuvering space next turn.  

Plan for next turn: after going DOWN, reevaluate whether to keep descending toward (4,3) or angle right toward (9,8)/(8,7) depending on enemy movement.

Next move: DOWN

1.rationale:
I'll check the distances from our current head at (2, 1) to each apple:
• Apple at (9, 8): 7+7 = 14 steps.
• Apple at (9, 2): 7+1 = 8 steps.
• Apple at (6, 1): 4+0 = 4 steps.
• Apple at (8, 7): 6+6 = 12 steps.
• Apple at (4, 3): 2+2 = 4 steps.

The closest are the apples at (6, 1) and (4, 3). Looking at their positions, apple (6, 1) lies directly to the right, while apple (4, 3) is up and to the right. To head straight towards the apple (6, 1), the first step from (2, 1) should be to move RIGHT, which takes you one step closer horizontally and avoids any walls or enemy collision.

Thus, I’ll move RIGHT.

Strategy for the next few turns:
• Continue heading right to eventually reach (6, 1) and grow.
• After collecting the apple, re-assess the board to choose the optimal next target.

Final move: RIGHT.

0.rationale:
Thinking:
• I’m at (4,8).  All four directions are safe; no bodies block any adjacent square.
• The closest apples are all 5 steps away, but the route to the apple at (9,8) is a straight, unobstructed horizontal line: 5 quick moves with no turns required.
• Moving RIGHT starts me on that line and keeps me near the board center vertically (y = 8), giving room above and below for future maneuvering.
• Enemy snake is far away at (3,1); no immediate conflict on the right side of the board.

Plan for next turn:
• Keep advancing RIGHT toward (9,8) unless something changes (enemy suddenly approaches, or a nearer apple appears).  
• Re-evaluate after each move whether it’s still best to continue right or divert down toward the (8,7) or (4,3) apples if they become closer.

Decided move: RIGHT

1.rationale:
Looking at our board, our snake’s head is at (3,1). The apples are located at (9,8), (9,2), (6,1), (8,7), and (4,3). Two apples are just three moves away:
• Apple at (6,1): It’s 3 steps to the right (from (3,1) ➔ (4,1) ➔ (5,1) ➔ (6,1)).
• Apple at (4,3): It’s 1 step to the right plus 2 steps up.

Both require about 3 moves, but moving right is direct and keeps our path simple along row 1. There are no walls or enemy snakes (enemy snake #0 is at (4,8)) interfering with a rightward path. So, the safest and most straightforward approach is to target the apple at (6,1).

Thus, my decided next move from (3,1) is: RIGHT.

0.rationale:
Thinking:
• I’m at (5, 8).  All four neighboring squares are empty and on‐board.
• Apples:
   – (9, 8) is 4 steps straight RIGHT.
   – (8, 7) is 3 steps if I go RIGHT → DOWN → RIGHT.
   – All other apples are farther; the enemy snake is far away (4, 1).

• Moving RIGHT keeps me on the clear horizontal lane toward (9, 8) and also lets me switch next turn toward (8, 7) if I prefer (RIGHT → DOWN → RIGHT).

Plan for next turn:
• After moving to (6, 8), compare the remaining distances:
     • (9, 8): 3 steps
     • (8, 7): 2 steps
  Most likely I will drop DOWN then RIGHT to pick up (8, 7) unless something changes.

Decided move: RIGHT

1.rationale:
Let’s reassess our situation. Our snake (ID #1) is now at (4,1) and we have these apples on the board:
• Apple at (9,8)
• Apple at (9,2)
• Apple at (6,1)
• Apple at (8,7)
• Apple at (4,3)

Looking at the distances:
• The apple at (6,1) is just two moves away if we head right: (4,1) → (5,1) → (6,1).
• The apple at (4,3) would require two upward moves: (4,1) → (4,2) → (4,3).

Both options are safe since the enemy snake is far off at (5,8) and there are no obstacles nearby. However, following our earlier rationale and considering that a rightward move gives us a very direct path to one of the closest apples, I lean toward continuing in that direction.

Thus, my decision is to move RIGHT, taking us to (5,1) and keeping our strategy straightforward toward eventually eating the apple at (6,1).

Decided next move: RIGHT.

Looking at the board, our head is at (5,1) and the apple at (6,1) is adjacent to our right. Moving right from (5,1) takes us directly to (6,1) which is safe and immediately gives us a point by eating the apple. The enemy snake is far off at (6,8), so no risk there. Although there’s also an apple at (4,3) reachable by moving up twice if we went upward, the right move gives us an instant benefit and continues our plan.

Thus, I decide our next move is: RIGHT.

0.rationale:
Thinking:
• Current position (6, 8).  All four neighboring squares are empty and on the board.
• A RIGHT step keeps every future option open:
     – From (7, 8) I can finish the straight run to the apple at (9, 8) in two more RIGHTs, or
     – Pivot DOWN → RIGHT to reach the apple at (8, 7) in two more moves.
  Either apple is three moves away, but staying on the high row lets me defer the final choice one more turn.

Plan for next turn (after reaching 7, 8):
1. If no one is threatening, compare which apple will still be closer/safer.
2. Likely sequence:
      • RIGHT → RIGHT for (9, 8)  (collect on turn-3),  or
      • DOWN → RIGHT for (8, 7)   (collect on turn-3).

Decided move: RIGHT

Thinking:
• Current head: (7, 8).  Safe neighbors:  
   – RIGHT → (8, 8) — empty, keeps both nearby apples a single move away.  
   – DOWN  → (7, 7) — empty, but then (8, 7) is the only quick apple.  
   – UP / LEFT are safe but don’t approach an apple.

• Flexibility: From (8, 8) next turn I can
     – RIGHT to (9, 8) and eat, or
     – DOWN  to (8, 7) and eat.  
  So going RIGHT now keeps two apples one step away and lets me decide after I see the updated board.

• Enemy snake is far (y = 1); no immediate contest.

Plan for following turn:
1. If both apples still exist, choose the safer one:
      • Prefer DOWN to (8, 7) if the top row begins to crowd,
      • Otherwise RIGHT to (9, 8) for the quicker chain toward the (8, 9) apple afterwards.
2. Keep center escape lanes open; avoid getting pinned against the right wall for long.

Decided next move: RIGHT

1.rationale:
I'll first analyze our situation. Our snake’s head is at (6,1), and our body currently occupies (5,1). Moving into our own body (i.e. going LEFT, which would bring us to (5,1)) isn’t allowed. Looking over the board, there are several apples, and the ones closest by Manhattan distance are at (9,2) and (4,3) (each 4 moves away). However, since moving LEFT to approach (4,3) isn’t allowed (our tail is still at (5,1) and that’d be a backtrack), (9,2) is our best candidate.

From our current position (6,1), if we move RIGHT we arrive at (7,1). That step moves us directly toward the target apple at (9,2). After a RIGHT move, our subsequent plan can be to keep moving right and then adjust vertically upward to eventually reach (9,2). There are no obstacles or enemy snakes (enemy snake #0 is at (7,8)) in our way.

Thus, the decided next move is: RIGHT.

0.rationale:
Thinking:
• Current head: (8, 8)  
  – RIGHT → (9, 8) gives an immediate apple but puts the head on the right wall, leaving only three escape squares (9,9 / 9,7 / 8,8) next turn.  
  – DOWN  → (8, 7) also gives an immediate apple while keeping four-way freedom in the center of the board.

• Future flexibility after DOWN: from (8, 7) I can still reach the (9, 8) or (8, 9) apples in 1–2 moves without hugging a wall.

• No other snakes are near; priority is to grow while staying mobile.

Plan for following turn:
1. After eating at (8, 7), evaluate whether to head toward (9, 8) or swing upward for (8, 9) depending on which still exists.
2. Keep at least two open escape squares each step; avoid getting pinned along the right edge.

Decided next move: DOWN

1.rationale:
Let's break down the situation:

• Our snake (#1) is currently at (7,1) with our tail at (6,1). We must avoid our own body.
• The nearest apple that suits our current path is at (9,2) (Manhattan distance = 3 from (7,1)).
• Moving RIGHT from (7,1) takes us to (8,1) — a safe cell and along the path toward (9,2).
• No obstacles (walls, enemy snake, or our body) block the RIGHT move.

Thus, to continue our strategy toward reaching the apple at (9,2), the next move is: RIGHT.

0.rationale:
Thinking:
• Current head: (8,7).  Neighboring squares  
  – UP    → (8,8) is my own tail, which will vacate this turn because I’m not eating now ⇒ safe.  
  – RIGHT → (9,7) is empty.  Would let me reach the (9,8) apple next, but puts me against the right wall afterward.  
  – LEFT  / DOWN keep me in the center but move me away from any nearby apples.

• Best apple race: both (8,9) and (9,8) are two moves away.  Going UP first keeps me off the right-edge wall and still lets me grab the (8,9) apple next turn.

• No other snake is within six squares, so I can focus on speed to the apple rather than blocking.

Plan:
1. Move UP to (8,8).  
2. Next turn, go UP again to eat the apple at (8,9) unless the board changes.  
3. After eating, evaluate a path toward the (6,9) apple while keeping at least two escape squares open.

Decided next move: UP

1.rationale:
Let's re-assess the board. Our snake (#1) now has its head at (8,1) with a body cell at (7,1). The nearest apple is (9,2) with a Manhattan distance of 2. We can approach that apple by moving in a way that brings us closer.

From (8,1) our safe options are:
• UP → (8,2)
• RIGHT → (9,1)

Both moves keep us clear of our own body, the enemy snake (head at (8,7) and body at (8,8)), and the board boundaries.

Choosing RIGHT moves our head to (9,1), and from there the apple (9,2) is directly above. This is a straightforward, safe path toward the apple.

Thus, my next move is: RIGHT.
